@abridgett please give this a shot regarding #1342 
@syvineckruyk it's very important for you to have a look at this -- I had to partially undo one of the fixes that kept SchedulerJob from preying on BackfillJob's queued tasks. That fix made it so SchedulerJob only dealt with its own tasks, but when SchedulerJob runs with `num-runs`, it keeps restarting and the new scheduler was ignoring tasks queued by the old one.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/5779694/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/5779694)

Coverage decreased (-0.02%) to 67.979% when pulling **8fa7fd487c59673c1163dee1b0631f4d49c6809e on jlowin:queued-tasks** into **5d15d6849ab8de5b835330a1ffced0690ee1a867 on airbnb:master**.

I might have found the problem. I was making many changes regarding the scheduler's behavior when this release candidate was cut and it looks like one of my PRs made it in and one just missed -- and the one that missed included a bugfix for this situation. Specifically, this one line (no. 823) https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/1290/files?diff=unified#diff-54a57ccc2c8e73d12c812798bf79ccb2R823

Without this line, the Scheduler's set of queued TI's doesn't clear even when they succeed, and the Scheduler tries to put them through again and again.

BUT this morning @abridgett raised a situation that may have been caused by the new logic when used in conjunction with `airflow scheduler --num-runs`, and I just submitted #1378 which undoes the changes in question and completely restores 1.6.2 behavior for queued tasks. 

Long story short: don't use 1.7.1rc :disappointed:

by the way @r39132 this was my test dag. @garthcn Does it exhibit the behavior for you too? I actually did NOT see the "previously succeeded" message in the logs for some reason, but I could see that it was trying to run the tasks.

``` python
import airflow
from airflow import DAG
from airflow.models import Pool
from airflow.operators import BashOperator
import datetime

session = airflow.settings.Session()

if not (
        session.query(Pool)
            .filter(Pool.pool == 'pool')
            .first()):
    session.add(Pool(pool='pool', slots=4))


default_args = dict(owner='airflow', start_date=datetime.datetime(2016, 4, 12))
dag = DAG('dag', default_args=default_args)

for i in range(3):
    BashOperator(
        task_id='op_{}'.format(i),
        bash_command="sleep 1",
        dag=dag,
        pool='pool')
```
Note the CPU is still pretty heavily used. The core running the scheduler is between 40%-50% pegged.

following is my airflow.cfg:
 [core]
airflow_home = /root/airflow

dags_folder = /root/airflow/dags

base_log_folder = /root/airflow/logs

s3_log_folder = None

executor = SequentialExecutor

sql_alchemy_conn = sqlite:////root/airflow/airflow.db

sql_alchemy_pool_size = 5

sql_alchemy_pool_recycle = 3600

parallelism = 32

dag_concurrency = 16

dags_are_paused_at_creation = False

max_active_runs_per_dag = 16

load_examples = True

plugins_folder = /root/airflow/plugins

fernet_key = cryptography_not_found_storing_passwords_in_plain_text

donot_pickle = False

dagbag_import_timeout = 30

[webserver]
base_url = http://localhost:8080

web_server_host = 0.0.0.0

web_server_port = 8080

secret_key = temporary_key

workers = 4

worker_class = sync

expose_config = true

authenticate = False

filter_by_owner = False

[email]

[smtp]

smtp_starttls = True
smtp_ssl = False

smtp_port = 25
smtp_password = airflow

[celery]
celery_app_name = airflow.executors.celery_executor

celeryd_concurrency = 16

worker_log_server_port = 8793

broker_url = sqla+mysql://airflow:airflow@localhost:3306/airflow

celery_result_backend = db+mysql://airflow:airflow@localhost:3306/airflow

flower_port = 5555

default_queue = default

[scheduler]

job_heartbeat_sec = 5

scheduler_heartbeat_sec = 5

[mesos]

master = localhost:5050

framework_name = Airflow

task_cpu = 1

task_memory = 256

checkpoint = False

authenticate = False
My system is centos6.5 and the python originally come with is 2.6.6. And I noticed the airflow is tested under python2.7.\* ,so I install the python2.7.10

Digging a little deeper into the problem, I am finding that the scheduler is firing the DAG just fine but it is scheduling the previous week execution. Is this the expected behaviour? Am I missing something? Is there something wrong with the implementation of the DAG?

I would appreciate very much some guidance to solve this problem.

Thank you very much in advance.
It seems to have worked today, will keep an eye on it - many many thanks @jlowin

@bolkedebruin maybe the `testdruid.py` file shouldn't be deleted but it I have always found it a little confusing that it sits at the top-level in its own "dags" folder. It isn't used anywhere in Airflow. Maybe it should move to example_dags? @mvfast does the file serve a special purpose for you? I think it's too specific to be useful to anyone else.
cc @bolkedebruin and @criccomini who have been looking at import timing
Relates to https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/1374
Same issue (different symptom) as #1348

To delete tasks, the easiest thing is to use the Airflow UI TaskInstance view, filter for the ones you want to delete, select all, and delete them all at once.

Deleting dag_runs can be done the same way.

Keep an eye on #1344, it'll make it easier to totally delete a DAG.
If 1.7.1 is bad, then I'd recommend dropping to 1.6.2, or waiting for the real 1.7.1 to be released (apparently the tag was pushed by accident).

I originally opened #1381 but I think this is a more appropriate place to mention it -- 

In order to mitigate confusion about the difference between `dagrun.execution_date` (the start of the "execution period") and `dagrun.start_date` (the end of the execution period, or the date the "execution period" is actually evaluated), suggest adding a "next scheduled run date" to the DAG UI.

See for example #1373
Closed in favor of 1028

Overall, looks good. A few comments:
1. I think @mistercrunch should have a look at this.
2. I think we might want a num_cores config in the scheduler to define the max number of cores to use. Right now it looks like the PR uses all cores on the box, always.

Haven't heard anything from @WesleyBatista. Does rolling back to 1.6.2 help?

Sorry guys, I could not try anything since I published the issue.
I want to try to do a downgrade to 1.6.2, but I am a little bit concerned about the issues with some database modification done on any commit.
Sorry not being able to be fully commited with this issue and not replying in time, but I will try your guesses :)

@WesleyBatista you should be able to downgrade the DB if you need to. From the dir where Airflow is installed, run:

```
alembic downgrade <checksum>
```

Where <checksum> is the checksum that you want to downgrade to. Checksums can be viewed in the `migrations` directory.

Cool then! :) thanks very much for the tip. I will try this tomorrow as
soon as I can.

@jlowin @mistercrunch . The issue is that subdag operators keep their slot and call "run" that uses a backfilljob and then waits for this process to complete, keeping its slot the entire time. Imho the subdag should not call "run", but should do a schedule. This allows the subdag to return right away and clear its slot. 

Furthermore, I consider being able to specify the executor on the subdag operator an issue as it allows someone to go beyond the resources that have been assigned by ops (ie. this is known and marked as such in the docs). However, by specifying the executor you can essentially tie the dag to a node and make it possible to share data via, eg. /tmp . I think that should be solved differently.
